Build something that lasts

Let’s go back to a simpler way of doing business

My grandfather is an amazing man. He’s 96 now. He served in WWII in the Pacific Front and saw action in Okinawa before returning home to North Little Rock, Arkansas to finally hold his firstborn child (my Mum). Soon after, he opened his own business, S&S Auto Parts. The purpose of the business was simple – fix cars. He was good with his hands and it seemed like a natural business to go into.

He continued as owner and mechanic for over 50 years and became a pillar of the community. People who brought their cars in would end up becoming lifelong loyal customers. A typical customer would sit down and have a chat with my grandfather over a bottle of Coke while his mechanics looked at their car. The business became much more than just fixing cars and it was very hard for him to sell when he finally decided to retire.

This sense of building a company or product for the long term does seem to be lost in the tech industry today. I have often had this nagging feeling that what I’m building is disposible. This is completely understandable in an industry that moves so quickly and builds products that exist only in 1s and 0s. Products that are so easy to copy and delete and alter. But I don’t think it has to be that way.

After 20 years in the industry, I am finally starting to see an internet that is mature. For so many years, we were battling with such piddling issues and wasting so much time trying to fix them. In my early days as a front-end developer, we had to use HTML tables to do any sort of consistent layout across the major browsers.

Now, we have so much control with CSS3 and all of the amazing Javascript front-end frameworks that almost anything is possible. And with frameworks, we’re spoiled for choice. We have WordPress and Drupal as the leading open-source CMSs. We have Angular and React becoming the leaders in Javascript frameworks. We can now build sophisticated applications that work across devices and provide an enjoyable user experience. We can now build software that won’t be so easily thrown away and rebuilt or redesigned in a year or two.

This is our goal at Bazzic. Go back to a simpler way of doing business to build products and relationships with customers that will last. Build websites and designs and campaigns that can run for the the long term and that directly improve our customers’ businesses. The relationship between the digital agency and the customer should be symbiotic. Together we can build something that lasts.

Nate Garbacz

Head of Web Development

Head of Web Development with 20 years of experience working on the web. Nate has worked in many industries, delivering websites for publishing, finance, e-commerce and software companies.
